author: timbeiko
content: ðŸ‘‹

author: timbeiko
content:
My 2c: re London
- I think the diff bomb is net good because it does push us to prioritize more aggressively what goes into forks (without it, we'd probably still be discussing whether to include EIPs into it...)

author: timbeiko
content: - I agree we need a longer period for stuff on testnets when consensus changes are done, especially when they require changes to JSON RPC and whatnot. We probably want several "iterations" to the JSON RPC spec when the consensus changes are final. IMO this is a good idea for the merge.

author: timbeiko
content: - I think it makes sense for me to chat with all client teams in the next few weeks to get a retro on what went well/bad for London, what we can improve for the next time, etc.

author: timbeiko
content: - Re: 1559 and investors vs. users, I think this is a false dichotomy. Obviously we're not optimizing for the short term price of ETH, and we likely can't, but it seems like a weird argument that it is somehow not right to make a change which improves the overall economics of the network _and_ is also beneficial for UX.

author: timbeiko
content: - Lastly, given that a lot of wallets and gas oracles won't support 1559 right at launch, I suspect some people will use that as an argument that "it doesn't improve UX". I disagree pretty strongly here: IMO it's totally fine for the protocol to ship the "building blocks" first and for there to be a delay for the ecosystem to adopt it.

author: sky.cactus
content: It is how EIP-1559 works.  Blocks will average around 50% full from here on.

author: lattechad

author: sky.cactus

author: lattechad
content: Why are there completely empty blocks?

author: shred209
content: That means some heavy loss for the miners?

author: sky.cactus
content: There have always been empty blocks sometimes due to the nature of mining and how competitive it is and how the speed of light is not instant.

author: sky.cactus
content: However, EIP-1559 introduced a new mechanism in London that results in blocks averaging 50% full, which means sometimes there will be empty ones just because demand is on a downturn.

author: trent_vanepps
content:
there are a few factors to take into account:

1. people wanting to send their first burn tx >> more congestion
2. people experimenting with new tx types >> more congestion
3. The upgrade is trending on social media, possibly leading to ETH appreciation from buyers who were waiting to see the outcome. market volatility (up or down) generally increases gas prices
4. miners are still targeting a lower gas target than before the fork block. it may take a while for this to stabilize

author: meekohi
content: Is it well understood why some pools post 0 txn blocks (something about the risk of mining old txns that then get included in someone else's block)? This isn't a new London thing right?

author: sky.cactus
content: Mining empty blocks is not new.  EIP-1559 introduces a new situation where empty blocks will be mined though, so we should expect to see more of them.

author: meekohi
content: <@!301186049323958275> I'm curious about the technical underpinnings of that. It seems like if you have enough "in-house txns", and you're a pretty big pool, you might have a strategy where you intentionally mine an empty block to drop the basefee 12.5%, and then hope to post a full block immediately after with the new lower basefee.

author: meekohi
content:
Some sort of calculation like
```
(chance of back-to-back block) * (1 - 12.5%)(current gas fee) * nInhouseTxns >? (avg tip) * nTxns
```
back of the envelope that seems like it'd be true for etherpool anytime they have more than a few in-house transactions?

author: potuz
content: Is this strategy correct? If so it's scary on PoS when you know you'll have the next block with certainty

author: sky.cactus
content: That is a losing strategy if you have less than 51% hashing power (and can censor).

author: meekohi
content: That doesn't seem to be the case?

author: sky.cactus
content: What do you mean by "in-house" transactions?

author: meekohi
content: e.g. transactions from your pools' members (who pay the burn fee)

author: sky.cactus
content: Ah, you are probably talking about selfish mining attacks.  There is a threshold where these become profitable when the value of a block is particularly high.

author: sky.cactus
content: Those aren't any different from regular transactions (at the math level).

author: meekohi
content: They are different, because a pool doesn't care if rando users pay a high basefee. They only would benefit from reducing the basefee if they have a bunch of transactions they want done.

author: meekohi
content:
So if I try and work an example for e.g. ethermine (25% hash rate) based on current numbers...
`(.25^2 chance of mining back-to-back blocks) * (.125% reduction in basefee for an empty block) * (0.004 ETH, current basefee) * nTxn > (.000004 ETH avg tip per transaction) * (300 txn in a full block)`
works out to ethermine should do this strategy anytime they have more than 38 txns they want to include in a block.

author: meekohi
content: ^In words, that's the expected benefit vs risk of intentionally mining an empty block instead of including transactions in it. You miss out on that block's tips, but then if you get the next block, you pay 12.5% less in basefee for your transactions.

author: meekohi
content: (doesn't have to be an all-or-nothing strategy of course, you could choose to only include a few transactions with big tips or etc)

author: meekohi
content: True, although this doesn't really do too much damage if it's only two blocks -- one empty followed by one completely full will reset the basefee for the next person. Maybe a little inefficient.
